Casa Loma Orchestra Signed
For Thanksgiving Cotillon
Event To Be Held At Belvedere Hotel; Band, Recording
And Radio Artists, Popular In
College Circles
Continuing a policy initiated
last year, the Cotillon Board, of
the Johns Hopkins University, in
planning an elaborate schedule
for the season, has scheduled the
Casa Loma Band, Brunswick Recording artists, to play at the
First Cotillon, to be held on
Thankgiving night at the Belvedere Hotel, following the HopkinsMaryland annual gridiron classic at
the Stadium.
Fourteen men comprise the
orchestra. The musicians' vocal
rendition of "Sweet Jenny Lee"
and "So Beats My Heart For
You" has received acclaim.
Kinney Sargeant, known as the
Casa Loma "play boy" has attained more popularity during the
past few months for what has
been termed his "appeal-laden
golden voice."
Played At Many Colleges
Between the fall of 1929--and the
spring of 1930 no other orchestra
played at as many college affairs,
it is claimed, as the Casa Loma
Band. Princeton, Pennsylvania,
Penn State, Amherst, Washington and Lee, Lafayette, Cornell,
and Vanderbilt students have
heard the orchestra play at their
respective colleges' social functions. This popularity in collegiate circles has been claimed as

the reason for the orchestra having been engag~d to play during
the past summer on the Steel
Pier of Atlantic City.
Cotillon Board officials have
expressed their apperciation for
the cooperation displayed by the
Hopkins students in the past and
promise bigger and better orchestras in the future.

Up Well In Lehigh
Tussle
Tonight Johns Hopkins' pigskin warriors will endeavor to retain their clean slate in their en·
counter with Swarthmore College. And an interesting battle
it should be.
The little Quakers have broken
even in their two contests this
season. In the first battle Swarthmore was defeated by a far
superior University of Pennsylvania team.
Lost To Penn
Throughout the first half, Penn
tried everything possible to crush
the Maroons, but succeeded in
scoring only one touchdown during the closing minutes of the
econd quarter. Swarthmore, due
to lack of reserve strength, finally
succumbed in the last quarter and
was overwhelmed, 32-7.
Last week the Maroons met an
opponent more in their own class,
and the Pennsyl;an\ians gave a
good acount of themsel~es.
Washington College, which was defeated by the Jays, 6-0, was
whipped to the tune of 20-0.
Maroons Stronger Than Jays
If scores mean anything,
Swarthmore seems to possess a
line-up stronger than the Jays'.
Most of the Maroon squad is
composed of men who were on
last year's team.
I ts backfield particularly showed
up well. Schembs, fullback, plunged
through the Washington line with
such frequency that Swarthmore
had little difficulty scoring one first
down after another.

ago.

have been improving daily. Last
week's victory showed a decided
advancement when a muchheavier
Lehigh team was trounced 20-12.

CROSS-COUNTRY MEN
TO MEET RICHMOND
The Hopkins Cross - Country
team officially opens its season tomorrow, opposing the University
of Richmond at Charlottesville, this
being the first meeting between
Hopkins and Richmond.
The team will leave today at 2 :30
accompanied by Coach Hambleton.
Seven men will make the journey
and compete in the encounter. They
are: Jung, captain, Glass, Sneeringer, Lewis, Mele, and two others
to be chosen from among Alpert,
Milstone, Pfetzing, and Hopkins.
Jung, Glass, Sneeringer, and Mele
comprise the letter-men and veterans of the group.
Expect Opposition
It is expected that strong opposition will be met tomorrow. Captain
Louchs, who does the mile in 4 :22 .
and Holden, helped considerably to
put Richmond U. in second place in
the Southern Conference last year.
The Hopkins harriers have been
preparing to run on what they believe will be a hilly course. A program of rigorous training has put
the men in fine shape, and it is
hoped that they will come out on
top.
On October 29 the Junior Varsity will meet the Poly team. All
candidates for the squad should report next Monday to Coach Hambleton.
